doc.after: Army engineers determined by 5:30Â p.m. on the first day that no one remained alive in the damaged section of the building.[78] In the days after the crash, news reports emerged that up to 800 people had died.[79] Army troops from Fort Belvoir were the first teams to survey the interior of the crash site and noted the presence of human remains.[80] Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Urban Search and Rescue teams, including Fairfax County Urban Search and Rescue assisted the search for remains, working through the National Interagency Incident Management System (NIIMS).[80][81] Kevin Rimrodt, a Navy photographer surveying the Navy Command Center after the attacks, remarked that "there were so many bodies, I'd almost step on them. So I'd have to really take care to look backwards as I'm backing up in the dark, looking with a flashlight, making sure I'm not stepping on somebody".[82] Debris from the Pentagon was taken to the Pentagon's north parking lot for more detailed search for remains and evidence.[83]
